newsitem.title: USA: Anti-tobacco lawyer sees study helping in trial.
newsitem.headline: Anti-tobacco lawyer sees study helping in trial.

text.p: The lawyer pressing a second-hand smoking case said on Tuesday a Harvard University study finding links between heart disease and second-hand smoke will figure prominently at a landmark trial scheduled to begin June 2.
"Our experts will be able to rely on it very significantly," attorney Stanley Rosenblatt said in a telephone interview.

The 10-year study to be published on Tuesday in the journal Circulation found that routine exposure to second-hand, or environmental, smoke nearly doubled the risk among 32,000 healthy women for heart attacks and coronary heart disease.

The finding may mean that as many as 50,000 Americans a year die from heart attacks caused by second-hand smoke, one of the study's authors, Dr Ichiro Kawachi of the Harvard School of Public Health, told the New York Times newspaper.
"This is the strongest evidence yet showing the connection between heart disease and second-hand smoke," Rosenblatt said.

Rosenblatt said he expects tobacco-industry lawyers to question the methods used to carry out the study and attack it in other ways during the trial, the first class-action suit against U.S. tobacco companies based on the effects of second-hand smoke.

The suit claims unspecified damages on behalf of an estimated 60,000 non-smoking flight attendants whose lung disease and other ailments were allegedly caused by second-hand smoke on U.S. passenger jets.
